Let $a,$ $b,$ $c$ be real numbers such that
\[|ax^2 + bx + c| \le 1\]for all $0 \le x \le 1.$  Find the largest possible value of $|a| + |b| + |c|.$

direct_answer.text:
Since $|ax^2 + bx + c|$ achieves its maximum when either $ax^2 + bx + c = ax^2 - bx + c$ or $ax^2 + bx + c = -(ax^2 - bx + c)$, it suffices to consider those cases separately. If $ax^2 + bx + c = ax^2 - bx + c$, then equating coefficients yields $ab = 0$. Similarly, if $ax^2 + bx + c = -(ax^2 - bx + c)$, then equating coefficients again yields $cb = 0$. Thus, one of $a, b,$ and $c$ must equal zero; without loss of generality, assume $a=0$.

Then our condition becomes \[|bx + c| \le 1,\]or equivalently \[\left| \frac{b}{c} x + 1 \right| \le \frac{1}{|c|}.\]For fixed $c > 0,$ let us plot both sides as functions of $x$; note that the left side goes upward while the right side decreases as $x$ increases over $[0,1]$. By

direct_answer.text: To determine the highest cumulative magnitude among the individual components $(\lvert\text{a}\rvert + \lvert\text{b}\rvert + \lvert\text{c}\rvert)$, we will examine various configurations based on different signs (+/-) assigned to $a$, $b$, and $c$. By doing so, we aim to achieve high values corresponding to large distances from zero—since taking the absolute values prior multiplies them positively irrespective of whether they were originally positive or negative. However, remember that changing the coefficients also alters the shape and location of the graph produced by the quadratic function $f(x) = ax^2 + bx + c$. Specifically, modifying $a$ significantly affects vertical stretch/shrink and flips open vs closed curves depending on its sign, whereas tweaking $b$ slides horizontally, moving turning points closer or farther away from the y-axis. Adjusting $c$ moves vertically, raising/lowering the whole curve uniformly unless combined with other transformations producing asymmetries.
